definition: A component that transparently stores data so that future requests for that data can be served faster.
When a requested item is found in the cache.
When a requested item is not found in the cache.
The process of removing an item from the cache to make room for a new item.
The process of removing an item from the cache because it is no longer valid.
The property that ensures that all copies of a cached item are kept up-to-date with each other.
A system of multiple caches, where each cache is responsible for storing a subset of the data stored in the caches below it.
The smallest unit of data that can be stored in a cache.
The number of processing cores that share a cache.
The process of dividing a cache into multiple partitions, each of which is dedicated to a specific task or set of tasks.
The phenomenon where a cache is constantly being filled and emptied, resulting in poor performance.
The policy that determines when data is written back to main memory from the cache.
The policy that determines when data is read from main memory into the cache.
A write policy where data is written to both the cache and main memory at the same time.
A write policy where data is written only to the cache, and is written back to main memory only when the cache line is evicted.
The degree to which a cache location can be used to store data from any location in main memory.
A cache where each location in main memory can be mapped to only one location in the cache.
A cache where each location in main memory can be mapped to a set of locations in the cache.
A cache where each location in main memory can be mapped to any location in the cache.
The policy that determines which cache line is evicted when a new line is brought into the cache.
